subject: Re: [junit] a question about abstract/parameterised tests
msgSnippet: ...  ... Nope, but if the rules for creating the subclasses of AbstractTestGraph are simple enough that you can do it using the reflection API, then
messageBody:
>So said Chris Dollin on 2003-08-07 --------------------
<snip />

>> You have an abstract test case AbstractTestGraph. There are a bunch of
>> implementations (subclasses) of Graph. You want to be able to generate on
>> the fly test cases for each implementation (subclass) of Graph.
>
>Yes. Specifically I don't want to have to write out essentially the same
>code
>once for each test subclass; the concrete test class differ only in their
>names
>(incidental, although useful when they fail ...) and in the class of
>object they
>instantiate (some subclass of Graph).
>
>> If that is what you want, then it shouldn't be that hard. Create a
>> TestSuite object consisting of dynamic subclasses of AbstractTestGraph,
>> each of which overrides makeGraph() to answer its particular
>implementation
>> of Graph. As I wrote, dynamic invocation handlers should do the job.
>
>It's generating those dynamic subclasses of AbstractTestGraph that's the
>problem for me. Am I missing something in the reflection API?

Nope, but if the rules for creating the subclasses of AbstractTestGraph are simple enough that you can do it using the reflection API, then there is no need to dynamically generate subclasses -- instead you need a better test suite builder, which I have just built.

I have just built ParameterizedTestSuite, which allows you to automatically build a suite of tests (from test* methods), but pass parameters to the underlying test fixture.

I will post an article on this today, since I am writing about it now. You can judge whether it gives you what you need.

Take care.
